page.title: 11LANGUAGE
page.content: Throughout Cornwall, the names of many towns and villages, also of houses and natural features, derive from the ancient Cornish (Celtic) language. Jack Ingrey, in his book 'St. Merryn - its Bays and Byways,' points to these local examples:- {Cataclews,}the word meaning 'grey rocks.' A quarry (disused) at Mother Ivey's Bay, and the stone from it, bear the name.{Dinas,}'Hill Fort'; Dinas Head lies west of Trevose Head. {Harlyn,}'Over the pool'. The village and bay bear that name.{Polmark:} 'Mark's Pool' or 'horse pool'.An hotel bears the name.{Polventon}means 'pool with spring.' An house by the Lifeboat House is called this. {Trevose}means 'farm by the wall,' or 'entrenchment.' The name of the princ- ipal headland, a farm, and by which the local area is generally known.
